title: Detecting Change
content: Your brain is wired to notice change more than static conditions. Leverage this by training yourself to detect deviations: sounds that shift, readings that move, behaviors that differ from normal. Change is often the first indicator that something is happening. If something feels different, investigate—don't dismiss the feeling.

mcq.question: You've been working near equipment for 30 minutes. The background hum changes pitch slightly but everything else appears normal. What should you do?

options.B: Investigate the change even though instruments show normal
options.C: Wait to see if it changes further
options.D: Log the observation and continue working

mcq.explanation: Change in sensory cues often precedes instrument indications. Your perception detected something; investigate to confirm whether it's significant before assuming it's normal.

openQuestions: What sensory changes are most important to detect in your work environment?
Describe a time when noticing a subtle change prevented a larger problem.
